3. Series of green flashes, meaning approach to land at the aerodrome 
4. Steady green, meaning cleared to land 
5. Steady red, meaning that the tower is closing

options.text: flight levels, if the flight is at or above the lowest usable flight level.
altitudes, if the flight is above the lowest usable flight level.

the same for both a flight over mountainous area or flat terrain.
for flat terrain, double the value of minimum altitude over mountainous area.

options.text: When an approach clearance has been received and descent begun and level flight is NOT expected during descent.
When cleared to descent below transition altitude while flying above the sea.
When cleared to descent below transition altitude and while staying within the control zone the entire time.
During an approach to an airport where no published transition level is available and when visual meteorological conditions exist.

continue on to destination, complying with last received and confirmed clearances or with filed flight plan.
adopt a VFR flight level and continue in accordance with VFR to the flight plan destination.
descend to Minimum Safe Altitude / Level and continue to the nearest aerodrome which has instrument approach procedures.

when QNH is higher than the standard pressure 1 013 hPa.

When, in airspace where VFR are permitted, the pilot-in-command of an IFR flight wishes to continue his flight in accordance with visual flight rules, until the destination is reached: - he must inform the control unit ("cancelling my IFR flight"). - he must request and obtain clearance. - he may request his IFR flight plan to be changed to a VFR flight plan. - the flight plan automatically becomes a VFR flight plan. in the aerodrome circuit, having established contact with the aerodrome traffic control.
on the movement area and flying in the vicinity of an aerodrome.

may propose another clearance. ATC has to amend the clearance in accordance with the pilot`s request.
has to accept the ATC clearance. The clearance is based on the ATC Flight Plan filed.
may request an amended clearance from ATC. Amended clearances will only be given when VMC prevail.

in so far as practicable to all aircraft having filed a flight plan or otherwise known by the ATS.

variant.question: For planning purposes, an aerodrome is categorized by aerodrome reference code. This code is composed of two elements: a number and a letter. What does the number relate to?
